title: Chicago's Most Haunted Bars and Taverns
excerpt: From Prohibition speakeasies to pre-Fire taverns, these are the Chicago bars where the spirits aren't all in bottles.

featuredImage.altText: Atmospheric vintage bar interior with dim lighting

content:
Chicago's bar culture predates Prohibition, survived Prohibition, and emerged from Prohibition with a collection of ghost stories that rival the city's official haunted landmarks. The oldest taverns in the city have been accumulating reports of unusual phenomena for generations—unexplained sounds, moving objects, spectral figures, and the pervasive sense that the after-hours crowd includes patrons who never left. Haunted pub crawls through Chicago combine the city's legendary drinking culture with its supernatural reputation. The best stops are not themed tourist bars but genuine working taverns where the hauntings are incidental to the business—places where the bartender might mention the ghost the same way they'd mention the daily special.

The Green Mill Cocktail Lounge

The Green Mill at 4802 North Broadway in Uptown is Chicago's most famous bar, and its history is inseparable from the city's gangster era. Originally opened in 1907 as Pop Morse's Roadhouse, it was renamed the Green Mill Gardens in 1910 and quickly became one of the city's premier entertainment venues. Al Capone claimed a regular booth near the back of the house—positioned, characteristically, near a rear exit that connected to the basement tunnels. These tunnels, used for bootlegging during Prohibition, extend beneath the building and into the surrounding neighborhood. During Capone's era, comedian and singer Joe E. Lewis was slashed across the face and throat after leaving the Green Mill for a competitor's venue—a warning to other performers about the consequences of disloyalty. The Green Mill still operates as a jazz club, its original 1920s interior largely intact. Staff report occasional unexplained phenomena: glasses that slide across the bar without being touched, cold drafts emanating from the tunnel entrances, the sound of voices from the basement when no one is below, and a persistent feeling of being observed in the booth once reserved for Capone. The bar's atmosphere—dim lighting, live jazz, original woodwork—makes it difficult to separate genuine phenomena from the natural effects of an old building with a famous history. This ambiguity is part of the Green Mill's appeal: it is a place where the past is so palpable that the boundary between historical atmosphere and supernatural presence becomes impossible to define.

Excalibur

The building at 632 North Dearborn Street was constructed in 1892 as the headquarters of the Chicago Historical Society. The Romanesque stone fortress survived the years and has housed various businesses, most notably the Excalibur nightclub. The building's pre-fire foundations extend below modern street level, creating basement spaces that feel significantly older than the visible structure. Paranormal reports at Excalibur span decades and multiple incarnations of the business. Staff and patrons have described apparitions on the upper floors, objects moving without explanation, and anomalous readings on electromagnetic detection equipment. The dome room on the third floor generates particularly consistent reports of a female figure who appears briefly and vanishes. Multiple paranormal investigation teams have conducted formal investigations at Excalibur, reporting findings that include Electronic Voice Phenomena, temperature anomalies, and photographic evidence that they consider significant. The building's stone construction and multi-level layout create an environment that investigators describe as unusually active.

The Red Lion Pub

The Red Lion Pub at 2446 North Lincoln Avenue presents an unusual case in Chicago's haunted bar landscape. Unlike the Green Mill or Excalibur, the Red Lion does not have a long history preceding its haunted reputation. The pub was opened in 1984 by British expatriate John Cordwell in a building that had previously housed various businesses. Almost immediately after opening, staff and patrons began reporting phenomena: objects moving on their own, unexplained sounds, a persistent presence on the second floor, and a general atmosphere of unease that intensified after closing time. Cordwell himself reportedly experienced phenomena and came to believe the building was haunted, though he was unable to identify a specific historical cause. The Red Lion's case is interesting because it challenges the assumption that hauntings require a dramatic origin story. The building has no documented history of murder, disaster, or violent death. Yet the reports have been consistent across forty years of operation, from staff members with no incentive to invent stories that might discourage customers.

Liar's Club

Liar's Club at 1665 West Fullerton has been a Bucktown dive bar for decades. Its reputation for hauntings is quieter than the more famous establishments but no less persistent among staff. Bartenders and regulars report cold spots that appear and disappear without pattern, the sound of footsteps on the upper floors when no one is present, and an occasional spectral figure seen in the mirror behind the bar. The building's history includes use as a residential dwelling, a commercial establishment, and—during Prohibition—possibly as a speakeasy, though documentation is thin. The hauntings, such as they are, fit the profile of many Chicago bar ghosts: subtle, consistent, and accepted by staff as part of the building's character rather than as a source of alarm.

The Old Town Ale House

The Old Town Ale House at 219 West North Avenue, adjacent to Second City, is one of Chicago's most beloved dive bars. The walls are lined with paintings by owner Bruce Cameron Elliott, including nudes of local politicians and celebrities. The bar has operated since the 1950s and attracts a mix of comedians, writers, neighborhood regulars, and tourists. Reports of unusual phenomena at the Ale House are sporadic but memorable. Staff have described hearing conversations from empty sections of the bar, feeling taps on the shoulder when no one is behind them, and seeing brief apparitions near the back of the establishment. The bar's late-night hours and atmospheric lighting contribute to an environment where the line between ordinary and extraordinary is pleasantly blurred.

Drinking with the Dead

Chicago's haunted bars share a common quality: they are places where the living and the dead (allegedly) coexist without much fuss. The ghosts, if present, are not dramatic or threatening. They are residual presences—remnants of previous occupants or patrons who apparently found the atmosphere agreeable enough to remain. For visitors to Chicago's haunted landmarks, the city's bars offer an accessible and enjoyable entry point. You don't need to walk through a dark forest or visit a cemetery to encounter Chicago's supernatural side. Sometimes, you just need to find the right barstool and wait.
